The recreate schemes action in fastlane (and the library it depends on) doesn’t support creating an Xcode scheme with tests. . @Goos FYI: [19:42:25]: ▸ ⚠️ /Users/travis/build/spotify/HubFramework/tests/HUBComponentWrapperTests.m:104:5: Null is returned from a method that is expected to return a non-null value [19:42:25]: ▸ return nil; [19:42:25]: ▸ ^~~~~~~~~~ . We should also make sure to move the Codecov step to be ran after both of the test lanes have executed. Otherwise we’ll be processing and uploading the same result twice for (in this case) the unit tests. . I have an idea of how to mitigate the “test failure reported as green”. Basically duplication of these things: - https://github.com/spotify/HubFramework/blob/master/Dangerfile#L31 - https://github.com/spotify/HubFramework/blob/master/Dangerfile#L34-L41 . @JohnSundell I wish! . @JohnSundell No we don’t want it to crash since it could, and should, just fail the test instead. Allowing the rest of the suite to run. Which will happen after this PR. The current behavior will be that the tests, if there’s for example CPU congestion, crashes and no other tests will be ran. Goos:
Awesome! 👍 
. @rastersize, @JohnSundell Yeah I was a bit surprised I was allowed to do that 😮  can I leave it or should we return something there in case future builds pick up the warning?
. Could you have another look @JohnSundell? Turns out we had a typo in the targetContentOffsetForProposedContentOffset:, yay testing!
. That sounds odd. As far as I remember, the UICollectionView shouldn't ask for a new count before the batch update, it should only compare the latest value returned from numberOfItemsInSection:, usually from the previous reload. 
Did you look at which points in time it triggers the numberOfItemsInSection:-call when this error occurs?
. @JohnSundell that's right! We're working on a third one right now :smile:
. Awesome stuff! 🎉
. Gotcha :smile: no worries
. Adding do not merge as it isn't tested yet
. Could we also avoid boxing them by using an NSIndexSet? We would still have to use reverse enumeration for them then though as they are implicitly ordered
. @JohnSundell I think it should be fine as long as the CI goes through!
. @goos, @cerihughes Updated the tests and fixed the style issues 😄 
. Wouldn't it make more sense if it expected a point in the scrollView's coordinate space though? Seeing as that's what frameForBodyComponentAtIndex: returns (and I know we're using it like that in a scrollhandler in a certain app :smile:).
. @JohnSundell Sure 😛 
. @JohnSundell Added a test case – mind taking another look? :smile:
. @cerihughes, @JohnSundell do you think it makes sense to call the scrollingWillStartInViewController: & scrollingDidEndInViewController: methods on the scroll handler when manually scrolling to a component indexpath? 
. @JohnSundell, @cerihughes unit tests are in place – would you mind taking another look? :smile:
. @JohnSundell fixed a bunch of stuff – mind taking another look? :smile: 
. Oops, that's right 😪 
. @JohnSundell the cause of the crash is related to the fix I did last week (https://github.com/spotify/HubFramework/pull/141) where the bounds-checking was changed as the view model child count might not align with the collection view's item count at all times. 
However, it seems like the numberOfItemsInSection: will actually trigger a call to the data source if the collection view hasn't done any prior item counts, potentially causing the collection view to report having more items than there are layout attributes for (as the UICollectionViewLayout is computed manually in combination with the reloading, which hasn't occurred yet). 
So the crash would remain if frameForBodyComponentAtIndex: was called after the view model was updated but before the first rendering pass. 
Yay UIKit \o/
. [15:09:30]: ▸ ❌  /Users/travis/build/spotify/HubFramework/sources/HUBViewControllerImplementation.m:1476:38: variable length array used [-Werror,-Wvla]
Don't we support variable-length arrays? It's been in the standard for a while 😛 
. @dflems good point – but doesn't that apply for most things C? E.g. sending an unintentionally large size to malloc :smile:
. @JohnSundell git grep is the shizzle :smile: 
. Hey @aliak00 – great catch, that's a pretty nasty bug! I reckon it's pretty hard to add a unit test for this since it didn't actually break before (other than wasting a bunch of cpu cycles) right? 🤔 
Regarding the failing tests – you can run the UI tests by running the test target in the demo project.. @krris fixed 😄 . @JohnSundell Got it! More documentation coming up. @JohnSundell, @nataliq I'm kind of hesitant to move back scrolling behaviour to the view controller as it's way too large already. How about exposing the HUBDefaultScrollHandler as part of the interface for subclassing instead?. No worries, still approved :smile: 👍 . I'm not entirely familiar with the original issue, but wouldn't a more robust solution be to increase/decrease the content offset with the change in content inset? E.g. if the top content inset changes from 5 to 15, decrease the current content offset with 10. Or does the UICollectionView take care of that by itself?. Awesome! 👍 
. @rastersize, @JohnSundell Yeah I was a bit surprised I was allowed to do that 😮  can I leave it or should we return something there in case future builds pick up the warning?
. Could you have another look @JohnSundell? Turns out we had a typo in the targetContentOffsetForProposedContentOffset:, yay testing!
. That sounds odd. As far as I remember, the UICollectionView shouldn't ask for a new count before the batch update, it should only compare the latest value returned from numberOfItemsInSection:, usually from the previous reload. 
Did you look at which points in time it triggers the numberOfItemsInSection:-call when this error occurs?
. @JohnSundell that's right! We're working on a third one right now :smile:
. Awesome stuff! 🎉
. Gotcha :smile: no worries
. Adding do not merge as it isn't tested yet
. Could we also avoid boxing them by using an NSIndexSet? We would still have to use reverse enumeration for them then though as they are implicitly ordered
. @JohnSundell I think it should be fine as long as the CI goes through!
. @goos, @cerihughes Updated the tests and fixed the style issues 😄 
. Wouldn't it make more sense if it expected a point in the scrollView's coordinate space though? Seeing as that's what frameForBodyComponentAtIndex: returns (and I know we're using it like that in a scrollhandler in a certain app :smile:).
. @JohnSundell Sure 😛 
. @JohnSundell Added a test case – mind taking another look? :smile:
. @cerihughes, @JohnSundell do you think it makes sense to call the scrollingWillStartInViewController: & scrollingDidEndInViewController: methods on the scroll handler when manually scrolling to a component indexpath? 
. @JohnSundell, @cerihughes unit tests are in place – would you mind taking another look? :smile:
. @JohnSundell fixed a bunch of stuff – mind taking another look? :smile: 
. Oops, that's right 😪

Interesting idea! How would HUBFeature work, is it like a mutable configuration object, or do you set it up once with an initializer? (Agree that the name HUBFeatureRegistration sounds more like a token than an actual model object).

@JohnSundell I wouldn't make it mutable, just instantiate it and pass it to the registry instead of calling the methods with all the parameters. Why not passing directly the model if you use it internally?. Regarding the name, that's the point, it sounds that it represents a feature + the registered state, and that's not the case. What do you think? 
. @JohnSundell I think it simplifies testing, you could have factories that provide you with the features that your app/apps need:
- You could test if the factories return the features that you expect.
- You could test if the registry gets the features from the factory. 
  Right now it's hard to test the registration process because the registration component imperatively calls the selector (in the example app you do it in the AppDelegate). What do you think?
  Regarding the naming, do you think I can just rename it, or should I provide any migration component/macro?

dflems:
@goos: Yes and no. VLA's can be dangerous. They (may) allocate space on the stack, so you need to be careful. For small value, it's very efficient, but if you inadvertently pass a large value in, it can have consequences.
In this particular case it's likely fine, but you could probably also get away with a fixed-length buffer and an assertion. Index path lengths usually aren't particularly long.
. @goos: True, true. In this case it definitely seems fine.

registeredCollectionViewCellReuseIdentifiersregisteredCollectionViewCellReuseIdentifiers keeps track of registered classes and will contain classes registered with a deallocated UICollectionView and the HUBViewRenderer keeps track of the last view model so it will calculate a diff against a different view model than the HUBViewController knows about.
. @spotify/objc-dev. @rastersize Definitely agree about migration guide from 2.0 -> 3.0. I didn't add one for this step since I think/hope that we have been able to separate the various parts enough to obsolete the HUBConfig as well before we stabilise for 3.x.
How about we add a migration path to the future PR removing HUBManager where you'll be forced to migrate and let the change to the demo app be the example for those that want to migrate earlier?. @rastersize re. initial view model registry. You can already handle it through the normal content loading by just having a content operation provide the initial view model without any network traffic.
Longer term we want to reverse the content loading (ie. the view controller has a setter for the view model and it's being fed from the outside, rather than pulled from the view controller. And in fact the view controller doesn't know about the view model loaders existens). That way the view model loader doesn't need to be involved in setting an initial view model.

@cerihughes, please see my comment on https://github.com/spotify/HubFramework/issues/264. This PR is most likely failing due to the empty body (Danger rule). . Thanks for the feedback.
A universal framework is much easier to maintain and that's a huge plus. The main technical argument against a universal framework was that Carthage couldn't build it but that's no longer the case. 
See these for context:
https://github.com/Alamofire/Alamofire/pull/326
https://github.com/Alamofire/Alamofire/pull/1064
Any other argument we should consider in favour of a platform-specific framework? 
An additional difference with @JohnSundell's implementation is that I added an explicit HubComponentWithFocusState protocol whereas John merged focus state with highlighted state. 
I will update the PR with the changes requested by @rastersize and @cerihughes and will steal a couple of ideas from @JohnSundell's branch 😄. Sorry for the delay in fixing this - moving countries is quite time exhaustive. This PR should be ready for another review (cc @cerihughes, @rastersize ). 
Summary of changes:
- Syntax was improved as per @cerihughes request. 
- Change requested re unsigned enums was applied framework-wide. 
- Change requested re configuration overrides was due to duplication of the dynamic target on production. Overrides were removed from both iOS and tvOS targets.
- The test target was improved a little.

I was intrigued by the fact that we were traversing the view hierarchy looking for specific subclasses and created an alternative PR - https://github.com/spotify/HubFramework/pull/285. @mumme, did a little investigation and it appears that the reason this doesn't work is that UISegementedControl doesn't implement any gesture recognisers and captures touches directly (thanks Apple).  . Strange that it's only causing a bug with Xcode 8.3 beta 2. @rastersize mentioned potential issues with apps importing as a module (e.g. Swift apps) and this kind of set up. Will run additional tests tomorrow. Don't merge yet. . @rastersize is right, this is not working as well as I hoped. . +1. +1. I like the sound of HUBViewController as a @protocol again. Something to consider for 3.0.0? . @krris, I did. HUBComponentContentOffsetObserver reports the content offset to components so that they can update themselves but I want to observe the contentOffset externally.. Small issue: adding a new method in the scroll handler protocol is technically a breaking change as it requires updating all classes that conform to the protocol.
I did consider making it an optional method but the fact that the scroll handler is of an "id" type and doesn't inherit from NSObject means I can't check if the the delegate responds to the optional selector. . @rastersize, can't wait :). @cerihughes, please see my comment on https://github.com/spotify/HubFramework/issues/264. This PR is most likely failing due to the empty body (Danger rule). . Thanks for the feedback.
A universal framework is much easier to maintain and that's a huge plus. The main technical argument against a universal framework was that Carthage couldn't build it but that's no longer the case. 
See these for context:
https://github.com/Alamofire/Alamofire/pull/326
https://github.com/Alamofire/Alamofire/pull/1064
Any other argument we should consider in favour of a platform-specific framework? 
An additional difference with @JohnSundell's implementation is that I added an explicit HubComponentWithFocusState protocol whereas John merged focus state with highlighted state. 
I will update the PR with the changes requested by @rastersize and @cerihughes and will steal a couple of ideas from @JohnSundell's branch 😄. Sorry for the delay in fixing this - moving countries is quite time exhaustive. This PR should be ready for another review (cc @cerihughes, @rastersize ). 
Summary of changes:
- Syntax was improved as per @cerihughes request. 
- Change requested re unsigned enums was applied framework-wide. 
- Change requested re configuration overrides was due to duplication of the dynamic target on production. Overrides were removed from both iOS and tvOS targets.
- The test target was improved a little.
